                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Geometrically, the kite can be inscribed in a circle if and only if it's the right kite, or the kite that has right angles. In other words, its long diagonal will be the diameter of the circumcircle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the radius of the circle in the question. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4r^2 = 36^2 + 48^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r = \sqrt{18^2 + 24^2} = 30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now considering the kite "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EFGH"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since all four sides are tangents of the circle, the radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will be the height of the the triangles with each side as the base.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, the area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EFGH"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times(\dfrac{1}{2}\times r \times (EF+FG))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since both kites are similar, the ratio of the sides are the same. That is, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EF = k(AB) = 36k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"FG = k(BC) = 48k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some constant "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, the area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EFGH"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30\times (36k + 48k) = 2520k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Alternatively, since the kite "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EFGH"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is made up of two right triangles, the area also equals "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times(\frac{1}{2}\times EF \times FG)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k^2(36\times 48"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1728k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solving for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we will get: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2520k = 1728k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k = \dfrac{2520}{1728} = \dfrac{35}{24}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, the area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EFGH"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2520\times \dfrac{35}{24} = \boxed{3675}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

The radius of the circumcircle of small kite, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R=\frac 1 2 *\sqrt{36^2+48^2}=30."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
But this is the inradius of the big kite. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
The right triangles are 3-4-5. If the kite has sides a, b, it area is ab, and inradius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{ab}{a+b}=r."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
A square kite with side 3,4 will have inradius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r=\dfrac{3*4}{3+4}=\dfrac{12} 7. \ And\  the\  \ area = 3*4=12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
So the ratio between the sides of big kite and this 3,4 similar kite is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k=\dfrac{30}{\frac{12} 7 }=\frac{35}2."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Area\  of\  big\  kite=12*(\frac{35}2)^2= \Huge    \color{#D61F06}{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ 3675.} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 101 for 100

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{array}{rc}
(1): &  x + y + z = 101 \\
(2): & 9x + 4y + \frac{1}{3}z = 100 \\
(2) \times 3 = (3): & 27x + 12y + z = 300 \\
(3) - (1): & 26x + 11y = 199
\end{array}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The only possible whole numbers for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore the numbers of peanuts is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{87}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I found that 3 is the value for Brazil nuts by using moduli."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that 26b+11w=199. I wanted to find what value of b, modulus 11, would make it congruent to 199. 26b is congruent to 4b, and 199 is congruent to 1. So now, we have
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4b \equiv 1 \pmod{11}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , which means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b \equiv \frac{1}{4} \pmod{11}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" . Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{1}{4} \equiv 3 \pmod{11} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , b=3, 14, 25, etc. b can only be 3 if w is positive, so there are indeed 3 Brazil nuts. From here, we can find that there are 11 walnuts and 87 peanuts. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hope that was helpful if you wanted to know how to get the value for b without guessing and checking. : )

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            How did you get that Only whole numbers for x and y are 3 and 11?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I used a system of equations: b+w+p=101 and 9b+4w+p/3=100.  I used elimination method to eliminate p from the second equation and got 26b+11w=199.  I repeatedly subtracted 26 from 199 until I was left with a multiple of 11.  199 - 3(26) = 121.  Then w had to be 11, and substituting back into the original equation leaves 87 for p.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} 
25x^2 + 10x & = -1\\
25x^2 + 10x + 1 & = 0\\
25x^2 + 5x + 5x + 1 & = 0\\
5x(5x + 1) + 1(5x + 1) & = 0\\
{(5x + 1)}^2 & = 0\\
5x + 1 & = 0\\
x & = \boxed{-\dfrac{1}{5}} \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" Limit"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" is "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x \rightarrow I^- "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can also write it as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"  x \rightarrow I - h "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here h a infinitesimally small positive number","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the expression becomes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{e^\left\{I - h\right\} - \left\{I - h \right\} - 1}{\left\{I-h\right\}^2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We replaced x by I - h where h→0 h \rightarrow 0 h→0","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now as we are aware of the property "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left\{x\right\} = x - \lfloor x \rfloor "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So following this property, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left\{I-h\right\} = (I-h) - \lfloor I-h \rfloor "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \left\{I-h\right\} = (I-h) - (I-1) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as the greatest integer less than III is I−1I-1I−1","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \left\{I-h\right\} = 1-h "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Plugging in the value of   "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left\{I-h\right\} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" into the main expression"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{e^{(1-h)} - (1-h) - 1}{(1-h)^2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Put "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" h=0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" into the above expression and we get "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{e^{(1-0)} - (1-0) - 1}{(1-0)^2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{e^{(1)} - 2}{(1)^2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow e - 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" e - 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the correct answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 101 to the 101

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of digits in a number is given by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lfloor \mbox{log of that number} \rfloor+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \log 101 = x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \log (101^{101}) = 101\times \log 101"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by the laws of logarithm. Therefore, the number of digits in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101^101"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" [101\times x] + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". It is given that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.004<x<2.005"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 202.404 < 101 x < 202.505"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the no.of digits is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lfloor 101 \times x \rfloor + 1 = 202 + 1 = 203"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lfloor x \rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the greatest integer function."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[LaTex edits. - Calvin]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"log(base 10)101>2.004--------10^2.004<101"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly, log(base 10)101<2.005--------10^2.005>101"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus (10^2.004)^101<101^101<(10^2.005)^101"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can then get 10^202.404<101^101<10^202.505"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The decimal representation is the number of digits in 10^202 (10^0.404 is single-digit), which is 100000....(202 zeroes), or 203 digits."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.004 < log"},{"type":"text","text":"10 (101) < 2.005 -->

202.404 < log_10 (101^101) < 202.505 --> 
10^202.404 < 101^101 < 10^202.505"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^202 has 203 digits (1 followed by 202 zeroes), while 10^203 has 204 digits (1 followed by 203 zeroes), and 101^101 is between them, so 101^101 has 202+1=203 digits. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as you can see 10^3 has 4 digits, using log 10^3 >> 3 log 10 = 3, then just add 1, it's 4!

I don't know, intuition. LOL
So 101^101 >> using log >> log 101^101 = 101 log 101, as you can see 2.004<log 101<2.005, so, 101x2 = 202, then add 1. LOL. YAY!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the law of sines on triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ADC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sin 150^\circ /1=\sin 10^\circ /DC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By the law of sines on triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"DBC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sin x/1=\sin (100^\circ -x) / (2\sin 10^\circ ) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"After cross multiplying and the sine subtraction formula, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\sin10^\circ \sin x=\sin 100^\circ \cos x- \cos 100^\circ \sin x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By the co-function identities, the right hand side becomes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cos 10 \cos x+\sin 10 \sin x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which simplifies to"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tan x=\cot 10^\circ = \tan 80^\circ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so our final answer is 80."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[Latex edits]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We observe triangle ABC is isosceles with its base angles  equaling to 40 each.
Clearly, we can see angle DCB=80 (by angle sum property of a triangle)
Now, we draw a line LM || AB through D. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
We can obviously say that D can’t be the mid-point of LM , since then angle ACD will become equal  to angle BCD (which is not so actually). Therefore, D lies somewhere else on the line-segment LM other than its mid-point. 
Now, we know that angle LAD = 10 < angle DAB = 30, we observe that as we place point D farther from  the mid- pt. of LM, from L , i.e.  when we consider LD > MD, then angle LAC becomes larger than angle EAB contradicting the given values. 
Therefore, we need to take, LD  < MD . 
Now, we mark another point E on line ML such that ME=LD, and so angle ECM=20 and angle EBM = 10 as they then become symmetrical. 
We thus get, angle EBA = 30.Also, angle ADM=150(since angles on the same side of the transversal equals 180, so 180 – 30 = 150) .Also, ADC = 150(from triangle ACD). Hence, angle CDB = 360 –  ( 150+150 ) =60.
 Similarly, angle CED = 60. Therefore, angle DCE = 60 ( angle ACD=angle BCE = 20 ).  Hence, triangle DEC is equilateral.
Now, in triangles CEB and DEB, we have,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"EB = EB  ( Common )"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"DF = FC  ( triangle DEC is equilateral )"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Angle DFB = Angle BFC = 150
Therefore, the two triangles are congruent.
Hence, angle BDE = 20 ( corresponding parts of congruent triangles are equal)
Hence, angle BDC = angle CDE + angle BDE = 60 + 20 = 80"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A little thinking (and drawing) shows that ABC is a  isosceles triangle whose angles are 40degree,40 degree,and 100 degree,....
. So draw it and put in D. Now, i am considering  another point E symmetrically placed on the other side from D. The point E must be within the triangle BCD...
So ∠ DCE become 60°. Since D and E are symmetrically positioned, CDE becomes equilateral.[like the triangle  ACD ]
Note that ∠CEB = 180 – 20 – 10 = 150°. So ∠BED will be 360 – 150 – 60 = 150°. 
Now join BD. It is easy to show that BED and BEC are congruent triangles. So BDC is isosceles and so ∠BDC = ∠BCD = 80°.   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let x= angle BDC.  We notice that angle BAC =40 degrees, so the triangle ABC is isosceles with AC =AB =a. We also get that angle ACD=100 degrees and the angle CDA is 150 degrees. 
From triangle ADB and the law of sines we get: BD/sin30 =AB/sin(210-x). From triangle BDC and the law of sines we also get: a/sin x =BD/sin 80, so BD= a* sin80 / sin x     (1) .   Let K be the middle of AB. The altitude from C to AB passes from K. So, cos 40 = AK/AB = AK/a = sin50.  Therefore BD/sin 30 = AB/sin(210-x) = 2"},{"type":"text","text":"a","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"sin50/sin(210-x) and since sin 30 =1/2 we get that BD=a* sin50/sin(210-x)     (2).   From equalities (1) and (2) we get: sin 50 * sin x = sin 80 * sin(210-x)  or  using trigonometric identities we can see that:  sin x * cos 40 = sin(x-30) * cos 10. But sin x * cos 40 = ( sin(x+40) + sin(x-40))/2 and sin(x-30) * cos 10 = (sin(x-20) + sin(x-40))/2. In other words:  sin(x + 40)=sin(x-20).  Solving this equation for 0< x<180 we get x=80. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let angle BDC be a. By sine rule,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC/sin(a) = BD/sin(80) => BC/BD = sin(a)/sin(80)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AB/sin(210 - a) = BD/sin(30) => AB/BD = sin(210 - a)/sin(30)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC/sin(40) = AB/sin(100) => BC/AB = sin(40)/sin(100)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC/AB = sin(40)/sin(100) = [sin(a)sin(30)]/[sin(80)sin(210 - a)]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin(40)/sin(100) = sin(40)/sin(80) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[sin(a)sin(30)]/[sin(80)sin(210 - a)] = [0.5sin(a)]/[sin(80)sin(a - 30)]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, 2sin(40) = sin(a)/sin(a - 30)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Multiplying both sides by cos(a),"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin(80)cos(120 - a) = sin(a)cos(40)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since there is only one solution, and a = 80 is clearly a solution. So angle BDC = 80."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \angle BAC = \angle DAB + \angle DAC = 40^\circ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , and thus  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{AB} = k_1 (\cos{40^\circ}, \sin{40^\circ}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" . "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k_1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  and  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k_2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  can be obtained from the fact that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{AB}-\overline{CB}=\overline{AC}=(1, 0) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , which can be written as simultaneous equations

 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 
and so  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k_1=\frac{\sin{80^\circ}}{\sin{40^\circ}} = 2\cos{40^\circ} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  and  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k_2=\frac{\sin{40^\circ}}{\sin{40^\circ}} = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The same approach is applied to segments  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" AD "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  and  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" CD "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , obtaining vectors  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{AD} = k_3 (\cos{10^\circ}, \sin{10^\circ}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  and  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{CD} = k_4 (\cos{160^\circ}, \sin{160^\circ}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  such that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{AD}-\overline{CD}=\overline{AC}=(1, 0) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" .  Thus scaling factors can again be found from simultaneous equations

 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 
giving  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k_3=\frac{\sin{160^\circ}}{\sin{150^\circ}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  and  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k_4=\frac{\sin{10^\circ}}{\sin{150^\circ}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We now find  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{BD}=\overline{CD}-\overline{CB}=\frac{\sin{10^\circ}}{\sin{150^\circ}}(\cos{160^\circ}, \sin{160^\circ}) - (\cos{80^\circ}, \sin{80^\circ}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" .  Its norm is

    \left(\frac{\sin{10^\circ}}{\sin{150^\circ}}\right)^2 + 1 - 2\frac{\sin{10^\circ}}{\sin{150^\circ}}(\cos{160^\circ}\cos{80^\circ}-\sin{160^\circ}\sin{80^\circ}) = \\
    4\sin^2{10^\circ}+1-4\sin^2{10^\circ}= & 1.
  \end{aligned}
 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \triangle BDC "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  is equilateral, and so  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \angle{BDC}=\angle{BCD}=80^\circ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Of course, more straightforward solution involves direct construction of the triangle  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ABC "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  and the point  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" D "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" .  The angle  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \angle{BDC} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  can then be measured from the sketch."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also, note that triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABC "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is isosceles with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AC = BC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If we let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \angle BDC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we can use the sine law on triangles "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ADC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"DBC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"or"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x <180^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", it follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 80^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: [10,20] is a Problem!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/solvable/b3dde7a83d.9d658601da.fK9oYZ.gif"}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle S_n = \sum _{ r=1 }^{ n }{ \big[(r-10)(r-20) \big] } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given the above function of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", what does the summation below equal to?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle  \sum _{ r=1 }^{ 50 }    \big|(r-10)(r-20)\big|  "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Image Credit: Wikimedia Cubix by Dohduhdah"}]}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{r=1}^{n} |(r-10)(r-20)| = A_n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{50}=A_{10}+A_{20}-A_{10}+A_{50}-A_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_n=S_n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" S_n>0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_n=-S_n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n<0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" i.e. for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" r\in ]10,20["}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence,  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{10}=S_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[A_{20}-A_{10}]=-[S_{20}-S_{10}]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[ A_{50}-A_{20}]=[ S_{50}-S_{20}]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{50}=A_{10}+A_{20}-A_{10}+A_{50}-A_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<=> A_{50}=S_{10}-S_{20}+S_{10}+S_{50}-S_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{A_{50}=2S_{10}+S_{50}-2S_{20}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

We call the (positive) sum of those 9 terms "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We then have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"SUM=S_{50}+2X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is also the difference between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Substituting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"SUM=S_{50}-2S_{20}+2S_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(r-10)(r-20)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is non-negative except for r in the range from 11 to 19. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Expanding on Hasan's notation, let's let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{r=m}^n |(r-10)(r-20)| = A_{m,n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{n} = A_{1,n}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{10} = A_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since the first ten terms of the summation are positive.  The next ten terms are non-positive, thus.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{n} = A_{10} - A_{11,n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"11 \leq n \leq 20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". 
Finally, as the terms for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n>20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are all positive, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n = A_{10} - A_{11,20} + A_{21,n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n > 20.  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The question asks for the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{50}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in terms of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{50}, S_{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{20} = S_{20} + 2*A_{11,20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and, indeed, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{k}= S_{k} + 2*A_{11,20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k > 20. "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Also, observe that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{10} - S_{20} = A_{11,20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
Substitute for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{11,20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the equation above to get the result "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{50} = S_{50} + 2*( S_{10} - S_{20}) = S_{50} + 2*S_{10} - 2*S_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There is a really simple solution to this.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Arithmetic sum formula.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle S_n = \frac{n(a_1 + a_n)}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the equation is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(r-10)(r-20)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", this means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{10} = S_{20} = \frac{na_1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You could solve the for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{50}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" but that would be unnecessary.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Just pick the result that add and subtracts the same number and your golden.  The one that cancels "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
